w:r.w:t: Homework #5
Construct a cache memory subsystem similar to the in-class demonstrations using these specifications:
Total cache memory is 128k bytes
Cache block size is 4 words (1 word = 4 bytes)
CPU address window = 32 bits
Cache memory chip size = 16k x 8-bits
Your solution should consist of the answers from Steps 1 through 4 (i.e. a 4-part answer) of the in-class presentation.
Step 1:
Step 2: 2^4 addressed is 4 bits
Step 3: 32-17 = 5 bits

Consider a direct-mapped cache with 32 KB of data and 8-word blocks and using a CPU with a 32-bit address window.
Determine the format of the address word used to access this cache.
What is the
total
number of
bits
contained in the cache block?

Since the minimum incremental amount of memory you can use is one byte (8 bits), if you were to build the cache memory from problem 1, what is the total size (in bytes) required for this cache memory?
Assume a 64 KB direct-mapped cache with a 32-byte cache line.
What is the miss rate for the address stream shown below?
Describe the general characteristics of a program that would exhibit very high amounts of temporal locality and very high amounts of spatial locality with regard to data accesses.
Describe the general characteristics of a program that would exhibit very little temporal and spatial locality with regard to instruction fetches.

You have been given 18 32K 16-bit SRAMs to build an instruction cache for a processor with a 32-bit address. What is the largest size (i.e., the largest size of the data storage area in bytes) direct-mapped instruction cache that you can build with two-word (64-bit) blocks? Show the breakdown of the address into its cache access components (for an example, see Figure 5.9 on page 469) and describe how the various SRAM chips will be used. (Hint: You may not need all of them.)
Construct a main memory subsystem with a total capacity of 1 GB.
Using 64 MB x 8 bit memory chips, build this memory subsystem.
Assume a word length of 32 bits and a 32 bit address space.
Show the address word used to access this memory and the breakdown of bits within it.
Assume that a particular computer system has an instruction word that is 16 bits wide and is divided into two halves.
The first half (8 bits) is the opcode, the second half is the operand.
Design a memory subsystem that is capable of storing these instructions.
Assume that you have only 8 bit x 256k memory chips.
How many memory chips does this require?
How many address lines must be connected to each memory chip?
How many memory cells does this require for each address?
Explain how the instruction words will look when stored in memory (where are the opcodes and the operands).
Pretend you are designing a computer system.
If cache is the fastest memory available, why don’t you include only cache in your system?
Discuss the issues involved in this decision.
